source.raw_text:
The Viking Press primarily targets the shoulders (deltoids), along with the triceps and upper chest (pectoralis major), while engaging the core, traps, and back for stabilization, using a dynamic, momentum-driven pattern similar to a push press or jerk, allowing for heavy weight lifting by dipping the knees and driving the weight up. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
This video demonstrates the correct form for the Viking Press: 
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers: 

    • Deltoids: Anterior (front) and lateral (side) heads are heavily recruited for pressing overhead, say Garage Gym Reviews (https://www.garagegymreviews.com/viking-press), Onnit (https://www.onnit.com/blogs/the-edge/how-to-do-the-viking-press-like-an-expert), and trainingstation.co.uk (https://trainingstation.co.uk/blogs/news/what-is-a-viking-press). 
    • Triceps Brachii: Extend the elbows to lock out the weight, note Garage Gym Reviews, Onnit, and trainingstation.co.uk. 
    • Pectoralis Major (Clavicular Head): Assists with shoulder flexion, say Garage Gym Reviews and Lippincott (https://journals.lww.com/nsca-scj/fulltext/2021/10000/the_viking_press.12.aspx). 

• Stabilizers: 

    • Core (Abs & Obliques): Braces the torso and maintains stability, according to Garage Gym Reviews and trainingstation.co.uk. 
    • Trapezius & Upper Back: Help stabilize the shoulder girdle and assist with scapular movement, note Onnit and trainingstation.co.uk. 
    • Serratus Anterior: Stabilizes the shoulder blades, note Garage Gym Reviews and Lippincott. [1, 3, 5, 6]  

This video provides variations of the Viking Press, including kneeling and standing: 
Movement Pattern (Dynamic/Momentum-Based) 

1. Dip: A quick, shallow bend in the knees and hips to load the lower body, say BarBend, Generation Iron, and Garage Gym Reviews. 
2. Drive (Legs/Hips): Explosively extend the ankles, knees, and hips to propel the weight upward, using momentum [2, 3, 4, 7]  

**Citations:**

[1] https://www.garagegymreviews.com/viking-press
[2] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PbYkdHEULrE
[3] https://trainingstation.co.uk/blogs/news/what-is-a-viking-press
[4] https://barbend.com/viking-press/
[5] https://www.onnit.com/blogs/the-edge/how-to-do-the-viking-press-like-an-expert
[6] https://journals.lww.com/nsca-scj/fulltext/2021/10000/the_viking_press.12.aspx
[7] https://www.facebook.com/coachnicx/posts/the-first-exercise-in-this-set-is-called-a-viking-press-%EF%B8%8F%EF%B8%8Fyou-can-use-a-machine-/586604357469689/
